But the only reason they're now incomprehensible scrambles of dots from a
human perspective is because you and I haven't grown up with the concept of
those particular scrambles as representing particular digits. If we had,
then we would probably be as able to recognize those scrambles as easily as
we recognize handwritten numbers.

Now certainly geometry is important for some (maybe even many) problems, but
it doesn't lend an advantage to every problem. And for other problems (e.g.,
document classification, non-board games like poker, time series analysis)
it's not immediately clear how to encode the problem domain in a geometric
way, and trying to force the problem domain into a geometric representation
may be more work than the return it gives.

On Sun, Apr 12, 2009 at 4:36 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>wrote:

>
>  As a thought experiment, let's imagine that we scrambled the order of the
> pixel array that represents these characters. For example, we might map
> pixel (0,0) to (4,2) (arbitrarily). Every other pixel is also mapped to a
> unique random location. Then assume that we use this same scrambled mapping
> on every example, so they are all still consistent. Unrealistically,
> assuming I understand the model, it will *still* learn the patterns just as
> effectively as before, irrespective of the fact that they are now completely
> incomprehensible scrambles of dots from a human perspective.
>
